prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for kicking a guy out of my hobby group because of his concealed gun?
I am in a little board game group that has been meeting regularly for the past six months. We used to have our game nights at a local hobby shop, but since we've gotten closer and the shop is in not the best part of town, have recently decided to start doing it at my house instead.

There's five of us total and one guy, "Jim" has a concealed carry permit and carries a gun with him. I know this because he's mentioned that he's always armed. I am very anti-gun but it had never come up before. Before our first game night at my place I told Jim privately that I don't want any guns in my house and that he would have to leave his in his truck if he brang it. He gave kind of an acknowledging but not exactly affirming response.

Then after our first game session at my house, one of the other group members told me on her way out that Jim had told her he still had his gun with him while I was in the kitchen out of earshot. I texted Jim and told me he had been extremely disrespectful and that this wasn't a game, and he could not come to my house again if he was going to have a gun on him. His response was "Fine, guess I won't be coming then," and he effectively quit the group.

The reaction with the rest of the group is split. One person doesn't care whether Jim participates or not, one person says it was "harsh but fair" and that Jim wasn't really kicked out per se, and one person thinks I am being a shrew and shouldn't have been so uptight about the gun after just one session, since he's never had to leave it behind before.

My point of view is that it's my house and my rules, and I don't think it's an unreasonable rule to not want a gun in my home. I put my foot down the first time it happened because it was a serious matter and not like he brought the wrong snacks or something. Jim keeps texting me going back and forth between saying "lose my number" and sending me links to propaganda supporting his viewpoint.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author of the Reddit-style post is in the wrong for asking a guy named Jim to leave their board game group because he had a concealed gun at their house. The author is anti-gun but had previously allowed Jim to have his gun when they met at the hobby shop. Now that they're meeting at the author's home, they set a rule no guns, and when Jim didn't comply, the author kicked him out. The group's reactions are mixed, and Jim is upset, sending mixed messages and propaganda links.

First, I need to consider the legal aspects. Concealed carry laws vary by state and location, but generally, if Jim has a valid permit, he's allowed to carry in public places. However, private property can set its own rules. So, the author as the homeowner can establish a no-gun policy on their property. Legally, the author isn't in the wrong here.

Next, the social dynamics. The author made their rule clear to Jim before the event, but Jim didn't comply. The author's action is about personal comfort and safety in their own home. It's reasonable for someone to set boundaries, especially regarding something as sensitive as guns. The author isn't forcing Jim to leave the group; he quit after being asked to comply with a rule. The author's firmness is justified because it's a safety issue, not a trivial one like snacks. 

The group's mixed reactions are expected. Some might see it as overreacting, but others would support the author's right to set the terms for their home. The fact that Jim is continuing to reach out with mixed signals and propaganda might indicate he's not respecting the author's boundary, which reinforces the author's stance.

So, putting it all together: the author had the right to set the rule, communicated it, and enforced it when violated. There's no indication of discrimination or unnecessary harshness beyond a reasonable personal boundary. Therefore, the answer is B.
